text: The language used by people in Delusions of Grandeur is a combination of French and English. This is because the play is set in a fictional city called Amsterdam in Holland during the Dutch Revolt in the 17th century. The Dutch language was heavily influenced by the Dutch language spoken in the Low Countries, which was a dialect of Flemish and was influenced by the Germanic languages spoken in the region. Delusions of Grandeur is full of people who speak to you. They're always in the room and they always look at you, and you don't know why you're so drawn to them. It's like you're being watched, and you can't escape their gaze. But there's more to it than that, I think. There's a sense that these people are trying to communicate with you, to tell you something.

Delusions of Grandeur is full of people who speak in the third person and are all in on a secret conspiracy. The story's protagonist is a man who wakes up in a hospital with amnesia, and he's not entirely sure how he got there. He's been in and out of consciousness for the past 10 years.
The protagonist's memories are fragmented, and he struggles to piece them together.

In Delusions of Grandeur, people speak in metaphors and symbols. They see a world that is both beautiful and dangerous. In this scene, they speak of the "wildness" that they find in their city, as well as the "fear" and "anger" that they feel when they are surrounded by people and machines. The metaphors used in this scene reflect the complexity of the world that the narrator has been brought up in.

In Delusions of Grandeur, people speak of the "greatest of all the world." In the context of the novel, it is the city of Paris, which is the "greatest of all the world." The phrase implies that Paris is the most important city in the world, and its importance is not subject to debate. It is a statement of fact, not a matter for argument or contemplation.
